description:
Rhinovirus A is a member of the Enterovirus genus within the Picornaviridae family. It is a small, non-enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus that primarily infects the upper respiratory tract in humans.

Rhinovirus A is the most common cause of the common cold, responsible for approximately 50-80% of all common cold infections. It is highly contagious and can be transmitted through respiratory droplets, direct contact with infected individuals, or contact with contaminated surfaces.

The viral genome of Rhinovirus A consists of approximately 7,200 nucleotides and encodes for a single polyprotein that is later cleaved into various structural and non-structural proteins. These proteins play crucial roles in the virus's replication, assembly, and host cell entry.

Rhinovirus A can infect a wide range of host cells, particularly the epithelial cells lining the nasal and upper respiratory passages. The virus utilizes various cellular receptors, such as ICAM-1 (Intercellular Adhesion Molecule-1), to gain entry into the host cells.

The symptoms associated with Rhinovirus A infection typically include runny nose, sneezing, sore throat, and mild cough. These symptoms usually resolve within 7-10 days, but the virus can occasionally cause more severe complications, particularly in individuals with underlying respiratory conditions or weakened immune systems.

Currently, there is no specific antiviral treatment for Rhinovirus A infections, and management primarily involves supportive care and symptom relief. Efforts to develop effective vaccines or targeted therapies are ongoing, as Rhinovirus A remains a significant public health concern due to its high prevalence and the substantial economic and social impact of the common cold.
